prompt: Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.
rubric:
Rubric for Patience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
essay:
Patience is a virtue that is often overlooked in today's fast-paced world. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure difficult situations without complaint. I have always admired those who possess this quality, as it is not always easy to remain calm and composed in the face of adversity.

One particular instance that comes to mind when thinking about patience is when my best friend, Sarah, demonstrated an extraordinary amount of patience in a challenging situation. We had planned a weekend getaway to the mountains, and everything seemed to be going smoothly until we arrived at our cabin and realized that the booking had been mixed up. The cabin we had reserved was double-booked, and there was no other available accommodation in the area due to a local festival taking place.

While I was starting to panic and frantically search for alternative options, Sarah remained surprisingly calm. She assured me that everything would work out and suggested that we explore the town while we figured out a solution. Despite the setbacks, she kept a positive attitude and focused on making the most of our time together.

After a few hours of searching, we stumbled upon a cozy bed and breakfast that had a last-minute cancellation. Sarah's patience and unwavering optimism had paid off, and we ended up having a wonderful weekend despite the initial setbacks. Reflecting on this experience, I realized the power of patience and how it can turn a stressful situation into a memorable adventure.

Patience is not always easy to practice, especially in challenging circumstances. However, it is a valuable trait that can lead to better outcomes and stronger relationships. I learned a valuable lesson from Sarah that day about the importance of remaining patient and optimistic, even when things don't go according to plan. I strive to embody her grace under pressure and approach every situation with a calm and patient mindset.

essay:
One day, my friend Sara showed me what it means to be patient.

Sara and I were playing in the park when we saw a little bird with a broken wing. I wanted to help it right away, but Sara told me we needed to be patient. She said that rushing things might make the bird even more scared.

So we sat quietly next to the bird, talking softly to it to try and keep it calm. Sara told me that sometimes, things just take time and we have to be patient and wait for the right moment.

After a while, the bird stopped shivering and started to look less scared. Sara slowly reached out her hand and gently picked up the bird. We took it to a wildlife rescue center and they said they could help it.

Thanks to Sara's patience, the bird was able to get the help it needed. I learned that sometimes, being patient and understanding can make a big difference. Patience is a really important quality to have.

essay:
once upon a times there was a bunny who was very patience. he was so patience that he waited for a whole day for the bus to come. he didn't get mad or angree he just hopped around and sniffed some carrots. finally, the bus came and the bunny hopped on. he didn't even complain about the long wait he just sat there quietly.

the end.

prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.
rubric:
Rubric for Laughter essay:

"6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter truly is a universal language that has the power to bring people closer together. I remember a time when laughter played a significant role in deepening the bond between my friends and me.

It was a warm summer day, and my friends and I had decided to go on a hiking trip to a nearby mountain. As we began our ascent, we were full of energy and excitement. However, as the sun beat down on us and the steep trail seemed never-ending, exhaustion started to set in. We were hot, sweaty, and starting to feel the strain on our muscles.

Despite the challenging circumstances, we found moments of levity that helped to lift our spirits. Whether it was a funny joke, a silly story, or a spontaneous burst of laughter, we were able to find joy even in the midst of physical discomfort. Our laughter became a coping mechanism, a way to alleviate the stress and fatigue that we were feeling.

One particular moment stands out in my memory. As we reached a particularly steep incline, one of my friends tripped on a loose rock and stumbled forward. In that split second, the tension and seriousness of the situation dissolved as we all burst out laughing. My friend, although slightly embarrassed, couldn't help but join in the laughter. It was a moment of pure, unbridled joy that brought us all together in a shared experience of amusement.

Through that shared laughter, we were able to forge a stronger connection with one another. It created a sense of camaraderie and solidarity that made the rest of the hike feel more manageable. We were no longer just individuals struggling with the physical demands of the mountain; we were a team, supporting and encouraging each other every step of the way.

As we reached the summit and took in the breathtaking view before us, I realized that it was our shared laughter that had carried us through the challenges of the hike. It had brought us closer together and strengthened our bond as friends. In that moment, I understood the true power of laughter in fostering relationships and creating lasting memories.

In conclusion, laughter is indeed a crucial element in any relationship. It has the ability to break down barriers, alleviate tension, and bring people closer together. My hiking trip with my friends taught me that laughter can turn even the most difficult situations into moments of joy and connection. I will always cherish the memories of that day and the laughter that filled our hearts along the way.

essay:
One time me and my friend Sarah were at the park playing tag. Sarah accidentally tripped over a rock and fell down. At first I was worried, but then she started laughing really hard. I couldn't help but laugh too, even though she was a little bit hurt. 

We both sat on the ground laughing until our stomachs hurt. It was funny because Sarah's laugh was so loud and contagious. We forgot all about the fall and just enjoyed the moment. 

After we were done laughing, we helped each other up and continued playing. From then on, whenever we remembered that day, we would start laughing all over again. Laughter really did bring us closer together. 

That day taught me that even in tough times, laughter can make everything better. I'm glad to have a friend like Sarah who can always make me laugh, no matter what.

The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Once upon a time, my dog went to the moon. He flew up in a rocket ship and saw lots of aliens. The aliens were very silly and they made my dog laugh a lot. They told jokes and did cartwheels. My dog barked and wagged his tail. 

Then, my dog came back to Earth and told me all about his trip. He said, "Woof woof, I saw funny aliens on the moon!" I laughed and laughed because my dog's story was so silly. We rolled on the floor laughing together. It was a very fun time. 

After that, my dog and I were even closer because we shared this funny experience. Laughter really does bring people (and dogs) together. I love my dog and I love to laugh. The end.

prompt: Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.
rubric:
Rubric for Resilience Essays:

"3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
"0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation."
essay:
Resilience is a key trait that can help individuals overcome challenges and setbacks in life. It is the ability to stay strong, flexible, and optimistic even in the face of adversity. I have personally witnessed a great example of resilience in my older sister, Sarah.

A few years ago, Sarah faced a major setback in her academic career. She had been working hard towards her goal of becoming a doctor, studying long hours, and doing well in her courses. However, during her second year of medical school, she failed a crucial exam that threatened her chances of continuing in the program. This was a devastating blow to Sarah, who had always been a high-achieving student.

Instead of giving up or letting the setback define her, Sarah showed incredible resilience. She took the time to reflect on what went wrong, seeking advice from teachers and mentors on how to improve. She developed a new study plan, seeking out additional resources and support to help her succeed. Despite feeling discouraged and disappointed, she continued to push forward, staying focused on her goal of becoming a doctor.

It was not an easy road for Sarah. She faced many challenges and setbacks along the way, but she never lost sight of her goal. Through hard work, dedication, and perseverance, she was able to overcome her academic struggles and eventually graduate from medical school. Today, she is a successful doctor, helping others and making a difference in the world.

Sarah's story is a powerful example of resilience in action. She did not let one setback define her or deter her from pursuing her dreams. Instead, she faced the challenge head-on, using it as an opportunity to grow and improve. Her ability to bounce back from adversity, stay strong, and remain optimistic is truly inspiring.

In conclusion, resilience is an important trait that can help individuals overcome challenges and setbacks in life. Sarah's story is a great example of how resilience can lead to success and fulfillment. By staying strong, flexible, and optimistic, we can overcome any obstacle that comes our way.

essay:
One time my friend Sara showed resilience when she fell off her bike and got hurt. She was crying and in pain, but she didn't give up. She got back on her bike and kept riding, even though she was scared. It was really cool to see her be so strong and not let the fall stop her from having fun.

Another time I showed resilience was when I failed a math test. I was really sad and disappointed in myself, but I didn't give up. I asked my teacher for help and studied really hard for the next test. I ended up getting a better grade and felt proud of myself for not letting the failure bring me down.

Resilience is important because it helps us keep going even when things get tough. It's like being a superhero and not letting anything stop you from reaching your goals. I think everyone should try to be resilient in the face of challenges, because it can help us grow and become even stronger.

In conclusion, resilience is a really cool trait to have. It can help us overcome obstacles and keep moving forward, even when things seem impossible. My friend Sara and I both showed resilience in different situations, and it made us stronger and more determined. So next time you face a challenge, remember to be resilient and keep pushing forward.

essay:
Patience is a quality that is often overlooked, yet it is crucial in navigating life's challenges without becoming overwhelmed. It allows us to remain calm and understanding in the face of adversity, showing tolerance and grace under pressure. 

One of the most memorable examples of patience in my life was when my grandmother fell ill and had to be hospitalized for an extended period of time. This was a difficult time for my family, as we were all worried about her health and well-being. Despite the stress and uncertainty that we were facing, my mother displayed remarkable patience throughout the ordeal. She spent countless hours at the hospital, providing support and comfort to my grandmother, never once complaining or showing signs of frustration. 

I vividly remember one particular day when my grandmother was scheduled for a series of tests that took several hours to complete. My mother sat by her side the entire time, holding her hand and offering words of encouragement. As the hours dragged on, I could see the exhaustion in my mother's eyes, but she never wavered in her patience. She remained composed and focused, determined to stay strong for my grandmother's sake. 

It was during this challenging time that I learned the true meaning of patience. I saw firsthand how it can make a difficult situation more bearable, and how it can bring comfort and solace to those in need. My mother's unwavering patience and compassion inspired me to strive for the same level of understanding and tolerance in my own life. 

In conclusion, patience is a virtue that should not be underestimated. It is a quality that can help us navigate through life's challenges with grace and composure. Whether it is staying calm in the face of adversity or providing support to those in need, patience is a valuable trait that can make a world of difference. My mother's display of patience during my grandmother's illness serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of this quality in our daily lives.

essay:
One time I was at the store with my mom. She had to return something and the lady at the counter was taking a long time. I got bored and wanted to leave but my mom told me to be patient. She said that sometimes things take time and we have to wait. I didn't understand why we had to wait but I tried to be patient.

It felt like we were waiting forever. The lady at the counter was talking on the phone and looking at her computer. I wanted to play on my phone or read a magazine but my mom told me to just be patient.

Finally, after what felt like hours, the lady at the counter finished and we were able to leave. My mom thanked me for being patient and told me that sometimes we have to wait for things to happen.

I learned that being patient is important. Sometimes things don't happen right away and we have to wait. Being patient means not complaining or getting angry. It means understanding that things take time and being tolerant of that.

I am trying to be more patient now. It can be hard sometimes, especially when I want something to happen right away. But I am learning that being patient is a good thing and it can help me in many situations. Just like I was patient at the store, I can be patient in other areas of my life too.

essay:
Once upon a time, there was a girl named Billy. She had to be patient one time when she wanted a cookie but her mom said she had to wait until after dinner. Billy was very upset and mad. She wanted to scream and cry but she knew that she had to be patient.

Billy sat at the table, tapping her feet and folding her arms. She was getting more and more impatient. But then, she remembered what her mom said about being patient and understanding. So, she took a deep breath and decided to wait for the cookie.

After what felt like forever, dinner was finally over. Billy's mom gave her the cookie she had been waiting for. It was the best cookie she had ever tasted. And she was proud of herself for being patient and not throwing a tantrum.

From that day on, Billy remembered the importance of being patient. She learned that sometimes good things come to those who wait. And she knew that being patient would always be worth it in the end.

The end.

prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
Laughter has always been a fundamental aspect of my family's relationships. I remember a particular moment that solidified the importance of laughter in our bond.

It was Thanksgiving Day, and our entire extended family had gathered at my aunt's house for a festive dinner. As we sat around the table, enjoying the delicious meal prepared with love, my cousin decided to share a funny story from his recent trip. His storytelling skills were impeccable, and soon the whole table was roaring with laughter.

In the midst of our laughter, my grandmother, who was known for her dry sense of humor, decided to chime in with a witty comment. This only added fuel to the fire, and soon we were all in tears from laughing so hard. Even my quiet uncle couldn't help but join in, his deep belly laughs echoing through the room.

As the evening wore on, the jokes and stories continued to flow freely. It was in those moments of shared laughter that I felt the true connection between us all. It was as if the laughter was a bridge that brought us closer together, allowing us to let our guards down and simply enjoy each other's company.

By the end of the night, as we bid farewell to our loved ones, the memories of that evening lingered in my mind. It was a reminder of the power of laughter in fostering strong relationships. As the saying goes, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people," and on that Thanksgiving Day, our laughter had brought us all closer than ever before.

prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.
rubric:
Rubric for Laughter essay:

"6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
"4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
"3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
"2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
"1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader."
essay:
One time, me and my friend Sarah were playing at the park. We were swinging on the swings and talking about funny stuff. Then, Sarah told me a joke and I laughed so hard that I almost fell off the swing!

We kept laughing and making jokes for a long time. It was so much fun to spend time with Sarah and just laugh together. It made our friendship even stronger.

After a while, we decided to go on the slide. Sarah went first and I followed right behind her. As we slid down, we both started laughing again. It was just so silly and we couldn't stop giggling.

Even though we both fell off the slide at the end, we were laughing so hard that we didn't even care. We helped each other up and kept on laughing. It was like nothing could bring us down.

That day at the park was one of the best days ever. Sarah and I learned that laughter really does bring people together and make relationships stronger. I'm so grateful to have a friend like Sarah who can always make me smile and laugh no matter what. Laughter really is the best medicine!
